status_message: In the islands, lunch time is all the time and everyone is welcome! If you leave hungry you're doing it wrong because at the luau it's all you can eat. Seconds and thirds are highly recommended. Make sure you try the traditional kalua pig! #EatPolynesia

What is your favorite part about the Polynesian Cultural Center! There is so much to see and do here and we want to hear what made your visit so special. 

PC: @lanifishy
Have you always wanted to learn how to dance Hawaiian hula? Well you're in luck because we can teach you the basics here at the center! PC: @glory317

Each island of Polynesia has their own unique style of dance and you can see all of them right here at the center during the canoe pageant! If you could learn to dance like any of the islands, which one would you choose?

HƒÅ: Breath of Life showcases traditional performances from the islands of Samoa, Tonga, Fiji, Hawaii, Tahiti and New Zealand! It's an unforgettable experience that has garnered international fame! Come see why everyone is talking about our evening show!

Bula Vinaka! Did you know that Fiji is made up of over 330 islands? Come to the center to learn more about the people who call this beautiful country home! 

PC: @annawojtas18

Many cultures of Polynesia are represented here at the center and all of them are very different and unique from one another. However, there is one thing that they all have in common and that is their love for song and dance! 

PC: @bestof.hawaii

Fire in the right hands it is a work of art! Come to the Samoan village and watch the dancers perform the traditional Samoan fire knife. 

PC: @amertz012

Here at the Polynesian Cultural Center we are very proud of our cultural heritage. As a result, we have preserved the languages and traditions of the islands. We invite everyone to come and enjoy the cultures of Polynesia. From our ohana to yours!

VC: @malinregnell

In Polynesia the kitchen never sleeps! When you come visit us you'll be able to try authentic cuisines straight from the islands. If you don't go home with a full stomach then you did something wrong!

Art has always been a part of Polynesian culture. You can see it in their homes, weapons, tattoos, and clothing. Here at the center you can experience each island and the unique artistic styles associated with them. 

PC: @strawberryoaks

Did you know that Tonga is also known as the Friendly Islands? They earned this name by the way they received Captain Cook and his crew when they first visited Tonga in 1773! Come watch their performance during the canoe pageant!

PC: @sinae9316

Have you seen all of the shows here at the center? Which one is your favorite and why? We love hearing about your experiences! 

VC: @aac113

Did you know that the Polynesian Cultural Center is spread across 42 acres of land? That's a lot of land! As you walk through the center you'll be able to experience six villages showcasing traditional housing, food, dances, artwork, customs, and language!

PC: @mickeyfryc

It's never a bad time to treat yourself to a fresh virgin pi√±a colada. Are we right or are we right? Come to center to grab your very own and enjoy life on the islands. We'll be waiting for you! 

PC: @noonchifoodies

Paddle your way through paradise in one of our self-guided canoes! This is the perfect way to take in all the beautiful sights and sounds of polynesia! This is an experience you DON'T want to miss out on. 

PC: @mayumi.n2236

Ha: Breath of Life is an award winner performance! It's an action packed show filled with fire, song, and dance. It's the best way to experience all the cultures of Polynesia in one show. Trust us, you do not want to miss out on this.

PC: @laurence.wong.photog

When you think of paradise, what comes to mind? This picture is real and it can be found right here in the Polynesian Cultural Center! Come experience 42 acres of tropical paradise and enjoy the many cultures of Polynesia.

PC: @car_lechateau

Random Acts TV is back at the #PolynesianCulturalCenter again! This time one man is tasked to do 12 random acts of kindness in under one hour. Check it out and then share with a friend, because we could all use a little more aloha!

Now that's one way to get rid of an itchy foot! Though we wouldn't necessarily recommend you try this at home. Come to the Samoan village to see first hand the traditional fire knife performance. You don't want to miss out on this! PC: @baddestchicano
How good does kalua pig sound right now? Here at the center the pig is slow cooked to perfection in the traditional Hawaiian imu. We're hungry just thinking about it! #EatPolynesia PC: @angguisky

Don't miss the boat! Next time you visit us make sure you hop in one of our canoes and enjoy a beautiful and relaxing ride throughout the center. It's a perfect way to catch a glimpse of all of the islands! PC: @suzanaraick

Enjoy Wonder Woman THIS FRIDAY, Oct. 6th, at 7:30 PM! Come to the Hukilau Marketplace Lawn to watch this amazing, action packed movie on the big screen and underneath the stars! See you then! #freemovienight #HukilauMarketplace #lawn #WonderWoman
A BIG aloha Friday to our ohana all over the world! Where is this weekend taking you? Tag your adventure buddy! PC: @jhophotography
Oh, hey Didn't see ya there! This just a friendly reminder that the weekend is ALMOST here so hang in there. Or in this case, hang ON! PC: @vasentaselvanayagam
The MƒÅori haka is not only performed as a war dance but can also be used to welcome guests and acknowledge great achievements! It's truly a sight to behold. Come experience it live! VC: @leexhan_na

During the 40th Anniversary of the Prince Lot Hula Festival, Cy Bridges was awarded the inaugural NƒÅmakahelu Oli Master Chanter's Award! Cy Bridges retired from the Polynesian Cultural Center in 2014 after over 45 years of service! His contributions to the center and the preservation of traditional Hawaiian culture are invaluable! Read more about his legacy in our blog!

http://bit.ly/2hp0tdX

status_message: You think twirling one fire knife is hard? Try TWO at the same time! The art of the Samoan fire knife is as beautiful as it is breathtaking. If you've seen it first hand then you know what we're talking about. PC: @holtphotographer

BIG ANNOUNCEMENT! With football season back in full swing, the Polynesian Football Hall of Fame committee has narrowed down their search for the Class of 2018. 18 potential candidates have been selected and on Oct. 10th, 2017 the five inductees will be announced! Stay tuned for more updates.

Are you hungry? Of course you are. Well you're in luck because here in Polynesia we LOVE our food. Come join us at Prime Rib Buffet for a delicious dining experience! Go back for seconds, thirds, and don't forget about desert. Prime rib and crab legs, what are you waiting for? PC: @dyalvinvincent

In Hawaiian hula, the dancers use their hands to tell the story. However, in Tahiti, dancers tell their stories with their hips! This style of dance is called Ori Tahiti. Tag someone who you think should learn how to Tahitian dance! VC: @classy_ambina
How many signs of beach or Hawaii addiction do you have? Not enough? Get more at http://bit.ly/2xpVDqc

status_message: Traveling to all the Polynesian islands would take a long time and not to mention A LOT of money! Luckily for you, we've brought the islands to you and you can see all of them by taking the self-guided canoe tour around the lagoon. PC: @travelhighs

If you want arms like these try grating a few coconuts! Come visit the Samoan village to learn the traditional way of preparing coconut milk. After the coconut has been grated, it is then strained through several fibrous strands called the tauaga! PC: @krxsphoto

As much as we like telling the world about visiting the Polynesian Cultural Center, we LOVE it when we can share the experiences of those who visit. Here is a great blog by Helena Kreis, an aspiring travel blogger from Australia. We'd love to hear YOUR experiences too!

http://bit.ly/2wnoabP
link_name: Through An Aussie's Eyes: The Polynesian Cultural Center - polynesia.com | blog

status_message: Age is nothing but a number! At age 13, this young dancer is well on his way to becoming a master of the Samoan fire knife. Come watch him as well as many others perform during the luau! VC: @aac113

In a world that demands so much from us, sometimes we need to take a step back and do a little self loving. Treat yourself next time you visit us and pick up one of our delicious pi√±a coladas. Promise us, you won't regret it and afterwards you'll be refreshed and ready to take on the world! #EatPolynesia PC: @dr_booyah

We are honored and privileged to call Laie our home! Laie has so much to offer. From the beaches to the mountains, there's something for everyone. If you're looking for family fun, thrilling adventure or a quiet place to get away from it all, visit our historic city of refuge and discover some stories of your own.

http://bit.ly/2wFkQeb

Happy Labor Day!
Did you know that September has more birthdays than any other month? Whether it's your birthday or someone you love take advantage of our 20% Labor Day Sale to Gift Aloha! Use code LABORDAY17 #giftaloha

Pani Popo, or coconut buns, comes from Samoa and is made from yeast bread and sweetened coconut milk. Pani Popo will make a delicious  addition to any occasion! Check out our blogpost for a more detail recipe. Enjoy!

http://bit.ly/2wtOzqc

Every year, fireknife competitors come from all over to compete in the  annual World Fireknife Competition here at he Polynesian Cultural Center. They represent the spirit of the fireknife dance by displaying their perseverance and commitment to the Samoan cultural art. A very BIG mahalo to Hawaiian Skies!

#ThrowbackThursday to when we had Villusion Studios visit us here at the Polynesian Cultural Center. Check out this awesome shot of the lagoon taken with a specialized 3D camera set up! Exciting things are in the works! PC: @villusionstudios

HƒÄ: Breathe of Life is truly an amazing show that you can only experience here at the Polynesian Cultural Center. As we like to say, "think broadway, then add flaming knives." You've probably heard the phrase "It takes a village to raise a child" before. Maoris raise their children together, participate in activities together, build, work and play together as a village unit. Learn more about the Maori culture by visiting our blog post!

status_message: What are your plans this Independence Day? The Hukilau Marketplace is having a huge celebration that is free for everyone! Join us from 5-11PM for live music, this year's Street Fireknife Battle, and more!

Join us in the Maori Village at the Polynesian Cultural Center for the Te Manahua Maori Arts Festival! Everyone is welcome! Come learn about the Maori culture as you witness amazing cultural performances from artists like Rob Ruha, Hawaiki Tu, and more! Taste traditional Maori cuisine, and try your hand at games and activities unique to the people of Aotearoa. Te Manahua events on Saturday, July 15, are included with all admission tickets. Admission is free for Kamaaina Annual Pass holders (ID required); and there is a $10 fee for those who only wish to participate in Te Manahua events. For further information, call 1-800-367-7060 or 808-293-3333.

status_message: Anyone else still thinking about this year's World Fireknife Championship? Congratulations, once again, to this year's champion, Falaniko Penesa! #WFCPolynesia #PolynesianCulturalCenter
A few more of my favorite pictures from the Polynesian Cultural Center's 25th annual World Fireknife Championship  and "We Are Samoa" high school cultural arts festival, May 11-13,2017:
link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

status_message:
CONGRATULATIONS to our 2017 Polynesian Cultural Center World Fireknife Champion: By a one-point margin, FALANIKO PENESA of Samoa (by way of Hong Kong Disneyland) won the World Fireknife Championship title this evening (May 13, 2017) in the Pacific Theater.

At the conclusion of the 25th annual event, the judges also named MIKAELE OLOA of Waialua, Oahu, the first runner-up, and KEPANIPA'A "PA'A" DAMASO of Waikoloa, Island of Hawaii, as second runner-up.
link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

FREE SAMPLE: After watching the Polynesian Cultural Center Samoan Village's informative, fun and authentic food preparation demonstration, the next logical step is to enjoy a free sample in the  "kitchen" area. In this case the young men are preparing bite-sized samples of "fa'alifu fa'i" or boiled green bananas mixed with coconut cream, and garnished with salt and onions. "Remember, this is just a sample, not your dinner," one of them says. MƒÄNAIA is the Samoan word for very nice. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)

The Polynesian Cultural Center will hold our 27th Annual Moanikeala Hula Festival in honor of our first kumu hula or hula master:

Aunty Sally Moanikeala Wood Naluai, who trained scores of young Polynesians in the art of hula from 1963 until she retired in 1980.

"At the PCC, Aunty Sally will always be remembered and celebrated as a beloved kumu hula," said Ellen Gay Dela Rosa, Theater Director and Aunty Sally's niece. "But her legacy lives on in Hawaii at this festival that brings together kupuna [elders] and keiki [children] to share and perpetuate the Hawaiian culture."

What an amazing showcase of skill and talent! #PolynesianCulturalCenter

The Polynesian Football Hall of Fame will be introducing the Class of 2017 Inductees during their 4th Annual Enshrinement Event on January 21, 2017.  As the home of the PFHOF the PCC is a major sponsor of the Enshrinement Ceremony but it is important to remember that this is still a private event of the PFHOF. There will be 3 separate events:

Celebration Dinner: Friday, January 20th Starting at 6:30pm at the Hilton Hawaiian Village Tapa Ballroom
                                                     

Enshrinement Ceremony: Saturday, January 21th Starting at 10:30am at the Polynesian Cultural Center
                                                                
ENSHRINMENT CEREMONY SCHEDULE 
Saturday January 21st 
10:00 AM Press Conference (closed to public) 
10:30 AM	Class of 2017 Gallery Dedication
Hall of Fame Gallery
11:00 AM	Enshrinement Ceremony Lunch
Gateway Restaurant
12:00 PM	Enshrinement Ceremony 
Hawaiian Journey Theater
1:30 PM	Autograph Session 
Hawaiian Journey Theater
2:30 PM	Inductee Canoe Parade


Inaugural Polynesian Bowl: Saturday, January 21th Starting at 6:00pm at the Aloha Stadium 
                                                                
TICKETS AND PACKAGE  INFORMATION 
A maximum of 450 tickets to the Enshrinement Ceremony are available for purchase. Interested guests can purchase tickets online at www.PolynesianFootballHOF.org at a cost of $25 per seat. Tickets are NOT AVAILABLE for purchase through the PCC and must be purchased directly from the PFHOF. Tickets normally sell out so advance purchase is recommended. The package included:

$25 Package
o Enshrinement Ceremony
o Special Luncheon
o Autograph Session / Meet & Greet
o Special Canoe Parade
o Bonus:  Free General Admission to PCC

For tickets to either the Celebration Dinner or the Polynesian Bowl please visit: www.PolynesianFootballHOF.org

Mahalo,
link_name: Polynesian Football Hall of Fame Enshrinement Ceremony

In remembrance of the 75th Anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor and the start of World War II, we hope you enjoy this 3 part series describing the events of December 7, 1941 and the ensuring war years from the eyes of three local La‚Äôie/Hau‚Äôula residents, Gladys Ahuna, Joseph Ah Quin and Laverne Pukahi.

SEGMENT ONE: La'ie Finding Refuge From the Storm - http://shop.polynesia.com/blog/12-7-1941

SEGMENT TWO: La'ie Under Martial Law; The Military Takes Charge - http://shop.polynesia.com/blog/Laie-and-martial-law

SEGMENT THREE: Mixing It Up in La'ie -  http://shop.polynesia.com/blog/Mixing-it-up

We are proud to share their memories and to honor the brave soldiers and citizens of Hawaii, as they faced war in their own backyard.
link_name: A View of Polynesia - PART I - Pearl Harbor and WWII Histories from La'ie: Finding Refuge From the Storm of December 7, 1941

status_message:
CONGRATULATIONS to  student employees Jamie Haeata and Timothy Ligaliga: Polynesian Cultural Center president Alfred Grace presented them with the annual Spirit of Aloha Award this morning (12/02/16) during a "team meeting."

Haeata is a part-Maori from Fukuoka, Japan, who has been working in the Guides Department. After he graduates from BYU-Hawaii this semester in marketing, he will begin working for a large U.S. pharmaceutical company in Kobe, Japan.

Ligaliga, a Samoan from Auckland, New Zealand, has worked in the Guides Department and the MƒÅori Village. After he also graduates this semester from BYUH with a degree in social work, he and his young family will return to Auckland where he plans to go to law school.

President Grace praised both of the young men and explained that the annual award "is the highest acknowledgement extended to a student employee," and that it honors the late Barbara Velasco, who own aloha spirit was instrumental in fundraising for the PCC and BYU-Hawaii. A generous donation from Keith B. and Carol Jenkins made the financial part of the award possible. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)
link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

WHAT: Christmas in Polynesia 

WHEN: December 9-22
The Hukilau Marketplace is open Monday-Saturday from 11:00a.m. ‚Äì 9:30p.m and is closed on Sundays. Holiday canoe rides during the Christmas in Polynesia event will begin at 6:00p.m. - 9:00p.m. each evening. 

WHERE: Hukilau Marketplace, Polynesian Cultural Center 55-370 Kamehameha Hwy, Laie

SUMMARY: Visit the Polynesian Cultural Center during the 13 days of Christmas holiday celebration for food, wholesome fun and live entertainment ‚Äì and take your family photo with Santa Claus! 
	
Holiday canoe rides will be $5.00 per guest. Free admission for those who present a Pepsi product upon entry from Monday-Thursday. Keiki can also enjoy festive train rides throughout  the Center, which are free for ages 4 and under and only $3 for ages 5 and older.

Tickets can be purchased by calling our reservations line 808-293-3333, or at our box office.

status_message: Bula Vinaka from the islands of Fiji!

Elder John H. Groberg, an emeritus member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints' 1st Quorum of the Seventy, delivered the keynote address at the opening session of the Mormon Pacific Historical Society's annual conference this evening, October 21, 2016, in the Polynesian Cultural Center's Hawaiian Journey Theater. Originally scheduled for the Tongan Village, the PCC moved the MPHS event into the theater when rain threatened ‚Äî which was just as well, since over 500 people attended.

This year's MPHS conference focuses on the formal centennial of the Mormon Church's mission in Tonga. Elder Groberg, who served there as a young missionary from 1954-1957, wrote an autobiography ("In the Eye of the Storm") of his experiences there, which was later made into the movie "The Other Side of Heaven."

Elder Groberg returned to Tonga as a mission president and in other Latter-day Saint leadership roles many times over the past 60 years. He and his wife, Jean, answered questions about their lives in Tonga following his address. (Photo by Mike Foley)

Bring the entire family and spend Independence Day at the Hukilau Marketplace at the Polynesian Cultural Center. 

The Festivities Begin at 8am with a Community Memorial Fun Walk.  The course starts and ends at the Marketplace and includes water stations, an inflatable 36ft slip and slide, water balloons, sprinklers and more‚Äìit‚Äôs fun for the keiki!  You can show up anytime between 8 and 11 and walk how ever long you want. Also, participants can include the name of loved ones in the military on their shirts to honor them.

After the walk, come participate in a Watermelon Eating Contest and Hot Dog Eating Contests. If you think you can make the best plate lunch, come enter and participate in our Plate Lunch Cook off.

For more information, visit HukilauMarketplace.com/events.

*8:00am - 11:00am WATER WALK
- Water stations, slip & slide, water balloons & more

*11:00am - 8:30pm HUKILAU MARKETPLACE SALE
- 25-50% off at all retail shops (Sale ends July 9th)

*12:00pm PLATE LUCH COOK - OFF CONTEST
- $15 entry fee / $50 fee to compete & sell food - Registration at 8am

*12:00pm HOT DOG & WATERMELON EATING CONTEST
- $5 Entry fee for each event
- Prizes include PCC packages, Ukulele & Gift Cards

Who knew baking banana bread was this easy. Try it yourself! #PolynesianCulturalCenter

Ingredients:
- 2 Cup Flour
- 1 1/4 Cup Sugar
- 3/4 Cup Oil (VIdeo has incorrect amount)
- 3 Eggs
- 2 tsp Baking Soda
- 1/2 tsp Salt
- 2 tsp Cinnamon
- 2 Cup Mashed Banana
- Chopped Nuts (Optional)

Directions: 
Place all ingredients in a large bowl. Stir to mix well. Pour into 3 small loaf pans with liners. Sprinkle chopped nuts on top. Bake for 35 minutes at 350 degrees.

link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

status_message:
At the start of the evening, May 12th, 18 senior division "warriors" from as far away as New Zealand, Japan, Samoa, Tahiti, and the U.S. mainland, lined up on stage in the Hale Aloha theater prior to competing for six semi-finalist positions and the opportunity to move on to the next round in the Polynesian Cultural Center's 24th annual Samoan World Fireknife championships. Then, over the next several hours, they shared their amazing skills.

In the end, the panel of judges selected the following six to compete again Friday evening, May 13 (in alphabetical order):

Kepanipa'a Damaso, Waikoloa, Hawaii; Viceson Galea'i, Laie, Oahu; Kuinisƒì Leiataua, San Diego, California; Mikaele Oloa, Waialua, Oahu; Falaniko Penesa, Samoa; and Matuni Vaiaoga, Orlando, Florida.

Three of these will be selected as finalists to compete during a special intermission of the PCC's evening show on Saturday, May 14th. The junior, intermedia and group divisions will also take place in the Hale Aloha on Friday evening. The next morning, the Pacific Theater will be filled with fans of the PCC's annual We Are Samoa High School cultural arts festival.
link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

So proud to see "Uncle" Cy Bridges (right) ‚Äî the Polynesian Cultural Center's recently retired Hawaiian culture expert ‚Äî sharing his deep knowledge of not only hula but also the origins of the chants and dances, as well as the genealogy and history of the k≈´puna behind them ‚Äî as a commentator for K5 TV during the 2016 Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo. Bridges was previously a multi-year judge for hula's most prestigious gathering and competition (which, incidentally, began the same year as the PCC ‚Äî 1963).

In addition to Uncle Cy, PCC's recently retired kumu hula Keith Awai is a first-time judge at this year's Merrie Monarch Festival (K5 TV screenshot by Mikaele Foley).

status_message: MAHALO NUI & CONGRATULATIONS to Keith Kalanikau Awai, who has retired from the Polynesian Cultural Center after 43 years of sterling service in the Hawaiian Village, theater department, as a performer, chanter, kumu hula and wherever he was needed. Awai, who is from Haleiwa, Oahu, said he will keep very busy ‚Äî starting with being a judge at this year's Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo, and extending to his hula groups in Washington DC and Japan. During its annual employee recognition program, the Polynesian Cultural Center honored Silina Turaga Aina of the Hawaiian Village for 40 years of continuous full-time service. In her remarks, Aina encouraged her fellow employees "to give your best every day."

Aina practically grew up at the PCC as a girl because her parents were among the employees in the early years of operation.

The Cultural Center also recognized several dozens of other employees during a special program in the Hawaiian Journey Theater on February 26, 2016, who reached various five-year milestones of continuous full-time service. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)

During a special Polynesian Cultural Center "team" meeting this morning (4 Nov 2015), President & CEO Alfred Grace presented former PCC Guest Services student supervisor F. Mathew Lotomau with its annual Spirit of Aloha Award.

Lotomau, a Samoan from Australia (originally from New Zealand), graduated from BYU‚ÄìHawaii on Monday (Nov. 2, 2015) and reports  next week to his new job in the front office of a Marriott hotel on the Gold Coast near Brisbane.

Keith and Carol Jenkins, friends of BYU‚ÄìHawaii and the Polynesian Cultural Center, endowed this award in memory of the late "Aunty" Barbara Velasco who worked with philanthropic donors to the two institutions and personified the aloha spirit. The PCC presents the award each year to a senior student employee who demonstrates the same spirit of aloha exemplified in the life of the late Aunty Barbara.

For example, Lotomau "championed" a get-well video that the PCC sent a couple of years ago to an 11-year-old boy who was going through degenerative heart disease surgery and, therefore, couldn't come in person to the PCC.

PCC Guides Services Manager Jimmy Mapu said when Lotomau's on duty, he "never had to worry, second-guess or fear for their team's experience, their customers' expectations, or the quality of their work. He leads by example and handles any situation that comes his way."

CONGRATULATIONS, Mat.

President Dieter F. Uchtdorf ‚Äî Second Counselor in the First Presidency of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints ‚Äî addressed the cast and crew of the Polynesian Cultural Center's evening show at the end of a long day on August 29, 2015. That morning. In response, they shared their aloha by singing Janice Kapp Perry's heartfelt song, "We'll Bring the World His Truth" (also known as "Army of Helaman," ¬©1983 by Janice Kapp Perry).

That morning President Uchtdorf toured the grounds of the PCC, dedicated the new Hukilau Marketplace, and then dedicated the new Laie Courtyard by Marriott hotel just makai (seaward) of the Cultural Center's Maori Village. (PCC video and photos by Mike Foley) (https://youtu.be/oSPtzluWR2Q)

Nobody dances on a canoe like Tongans do. #AlohaPCC #LetHawaiiHappen

President Uchtdorf, his wife Harriet and the visiting group met with the cast after the PCC evening show tonight (8/29/15): He spoke to them briefly, and they sang "We Are As the Army of Helaman."

The Hukilau Marketplace is just about to start Insurgent! Come out for the FREE movie night under the stars tonight at 8pm.

President Dieter F. Uchtdorf, Second Counselor in the First Presidency of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which founded the PCC in 1963, dedicated the new Hukilau Marketplace at the Polynesian Cultural Center this morning (8/29/15) in front of a large crowd. After the PCC event, he and the official party moved on to the Laie Courtyard by Marriott in another large Hawaiian and community program, he also dedicated the new hotel. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)

status_message: Hale Motu'apuaka from Aiea, Oahu, 15, took first place in the intermediate division (ages 12-17) of the Polynesian Cultural Center's 23rd annual Samoan World Fireknife Championship this evening, May 8, 2015, in the Hale Aloha theater. Motu'apuaka has been participating in the annual event for the past 12 years. That's right! (PCC photo by OG Mikaele Foley)

Congrats to our 3 fireknife dancing finalists: VJ Tiumalu, Joseph Caduosteau, and Mikaele Oloa! They will be competing in the final round Saturday night at 8:00p (HST) for the World Championship. Tune in live on our Facebook page!

status_message: Mahalo to another 40 year recipient John Muaina.
Thank you to sister Regina Pasi for your 40 years of service. She started working at the Polynesian Cultural Center at 9 years old.
Thank you Logo for your 30 years of service at the Polynesian Cultural Center.
Congratulations to Fifita Unga for your 35 years of service at the Polynesian Cultural Center.

WAY TASTY: PCC's new POUNDERS Restaurant's HAWAIIAN PIZZA ‚Äî one of the most popular in their line-up of 10 all-new creations ‚Äî is "killer" delicious. This Neapolitan-style pizza ‚Äî cooked in Pounders' kiawe-wood-burning brick oven imported from Italy ‚Äî features a base of hand-pressed caputo flour (also imported) dough, with crispy prosciutto and smoked mozzarella cheese, accented with arugula greens and tangy mango chutney sauce. You gotta' try it!

Former PCC student carver Leroy Transfield, a Maori from Wellington, New Zealand, who graduated with BFA degree from BYU-Hawaii in 1993, sculpted the imposing new statue of Hamana Kalili that is part of the Polynesian Cultural Center's new Hukilau Marketplace in just five weeks.

Kalili, a large Hawaiian from Laie, lost three fingers of his right hand in an industrial accident. His subsequent wave ‚Äî while portraying King Kamehameha in the old Laie Hukilau, with the little finger-and-thumb extended ‚Äî has since spread around the world and is now known as the "shaka" sign.

"Before I signed the contract, I thought about it for a whole week, and I said to myself, I‚Äôm not sure it can be done," he said. "However, it came together easier and faster than I ever thought that it would. Even now that it‚Äôs finished, I can hardly believe how quickly and how well it turned out.‚Äù

Transfield has also completed a sculpture of Joseph Kekuku, another Hawaiian native of Laie, who invented the unique Hawaiian steel guitar. That statue will be put on display as part of a planned new ukulele factory at the Polynesian Cultural Center. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)
link_name: Photos from Polynesian Cultural Center's post

Mahalo!
A beautiful story about Laie, its history, and the origins of the Polynesian Cultural Center.

The Polynesian Cultural Center, in addition to inviting community k≈´puna (elders) to attend a special ceremony for the official opening of its new Hukilau Marketplace, also three a free bash for the community and public this evening. Highlights included a local "stew-au" ‚Äî beef stew and rice, with "pake" cake (Chinese cookies) and soda ‚Äîthat was kinda' common back in the day, fitting with the retro-theme of the exciting new addition to the Center.

status_message:
START HOLDING YOUR BREATH for the upcoming POUNDER'S GRILL in the PCC's new HUKILAU MARKETPLACE: 

Chef Sean Priester, who has 30 years of experience ‚Äî 20-plus of them in Hawaii ‚Äî will operate the restaurant independent of PCC Food Services. He's putting together a Pacific Rim fusion menu that's going to feature ‚Äî just naming them is enough to whet your appetite ‚Äî seafood, of course; kajiki and ahi poke, steaks, pipikaula, kicked-up fried rice and saimin, crab cakes, great sandwiches, salads of course, and sumptuous desserts. The open kitchen's centerpiece wood-burning brick oven will also bake delicious pizzas; and much more.

Dine inside in air-conditioned comfort; or relax on the covered, open-air lanai while watching entertainment in the gazebo.

It's coming! POUNDER'S ‚Äî not the beach, the next time you're thinking of that special dinner.
Mahalo to Twilight actor Jackson Rathborne for visiting the center yesterday.

Aloha Friday contest. Our PCC truck is somewhere out in Honolulu delivering one of our new food trucks to our Hukilau Marketplace.  The first person to post a pic of the truck will win two free Annual Passes to the center.

As the PCC's exciting new Hukilau Marketplace gradually opens, we took the time to enjoy Kawika's Koolers' ‚Äî that's just one of the kiosks ‚Äî very generous-portion A√ßa√≠ Bowl, which is their most popular item on day-one. It consists of blended fruit smoothie, apple juice, French vanilla/almond granola, sliced ripe banana and strawberries, drizzled with honey.

 image from this morning's ceremony marking the opening of the PCC Samoan Village's new chief's house. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)

UMUSAGA of the new SAMOAN CHIEF'S HOUSE:  Samoan Villagers and invited guests celebrated the official opening (umusaga) of their new chief's house this morning, September 20, 2014, with a short ceremony and blessing on the house, followed by traditional speeches, presentation of good and mats to VIPs, entertainment, and a feast for everyone. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)

status_message: IOSEPA READY TO SAIL AGAIN: The BYU‚ÄìHawaii/Polynesian Cultural Center's 57-foot traditional twin-hulled Hawaiian sailing canoe or wa'a kaulua will soon leave its permanent berth in the PCC's Hawaiian Village for one of its periodic ocean voyages. The sail plan tentatively calls for Iosepa to sail along Windward Oahu, with stops at Kualoa, Kahana and Haleiwa, and also to the island of Kauai, weather permitting. (PCC photos by Mike Foley)

status_message:
The Polynesian Cultural Center (PCC) will be closed today, Friday, August 8, due to the severe weather from Hurricane Iselle affecting O'ahu. 
Guests with previous reservations are instructed to contact their travel agent or the PCC ticket office at (800) 367-7060 or on O'ahu, call (808) 293-3333.
Happy Aloha Friday! Stay safe everyone.
The Polynesian Cultural Center will be closed today, Friday, August 8, due to the severe weather from Hurricane Iselle affecting O'ahu.

The Polynesian Cultural Center (PCC) will be closed tomorrow, Friday, August 8, due to the severe weather from Hurricane Iselle affecting Oahu. 

 "The health and safety of our guests and employees always come first here at the Polynesian Cultural Center," said Alfred Grace, PCC's President and CEO.

The PCC is expected to reopen on Saturday for regular operating hours from 12 noon to 9:30 p.m. unless otherwise notified.

Guests with previous reservations are instructed to contact their travel agent or the PCC ticket office from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. HST at (800) 367-7060 or on Oahu, call (808) 293-3333.

Heeding the warnings of severe weather coming from Hurricane Iselle, we will be canceling the Common Kings concert scheduled for tonight at the Pacific Theater. The safety of our employees and guests is always our main priority. If you purchased tickets directly from the Polynesian Cultural Center, please contact our box office at 808-293-3333 for a full refund. If you purchased tickets elsewhere, please contact the appropriate promoter or vendor. We apologize for the inconvenience.

status_message:
Tamure Marathon will be held at Polynesian Cultural Center for 3 separate days starting from this Friday.

It will be 3 hours of non-stop hip-shaking that causes great cardio, legs and full body exercise!

Darsha Brothers was one of the instructors for Tamure Marathon last year. She is from Cook Islands and used to be a dancer at the center.
She said ever since she can remember, she was learning how to dance on her mom‚Äôs lap. To her tamure is her second nature, part of DNA and also part of the identity that brings a sense of belonging and familiarity.

This event Tamure Marathon is for anyone to feel happy through enjoyment, fitness and also socializing that come from dancing together.

We are looking forward to seeing you at Tahitian Village!

- Schedule
Fri Jun 20             5:30pm ‚Äì 8:30pm
Fri Jun 27             5:30pm ‚Äì 8:30pm
Sat Jul 5               7:30am ‚Äì 10:30am
 
- Loctation
Tahitian Village  ‚Äì park at BYU-Hawaii and enter through side gate directly into Tahitian Village. 

- Ticket
Tickets will be available near side gate
$10/person/day  (whether they are participating or just watching)

$25/person for 3-day participation
Annual Pass holders - free

One of our guests returned to the Polynesian Cultural Center last week after 23 years and shared this story that touched the hearts of our entire PCC ohana. 

One of our longtime employees, says it best...we have a wonderful responsibility and opportunity to share a little bit of paradise with every guest who comes through our doors.

"Mahalo Donna for returning this special memento to PCC. A hui hou (until we meet again)....ALOHA"

Original Post:
Donna and her husband visited Polynesian Cultural Center (PCC) back in 1991 (23 years ago) and when they bought a souvenir at one of the shops, received this $5 bill as part of their change. It has a Deposit stamp to Bank of Hawaii with the Polynesian Cultural Center name (look closely at the last two lines of the red stamp). They thought that was a fun little thing that would remind them of the great time they had here, so for all these years, they kept the bill and promised each other that they would someday return to their personal paradise here in Hawaii and the PCC. Sadly, a few years ago her husband fell ill and passed away. Donna decided that she would fulfill her promise, albeit alone, to return to Hawaii. She came to the Center, handed us this bill and said, "The PCC is a paradise to us so returning this bill to the PCC makes me feel like I'm returning my husband's soul to dwell here in this paradise forever!" This special $5 bill is going to be framed and hung in the Guest Services Office as a daily reminder that we have the wonderful opportunity and responsibility to help create a little bit of paradise on earth for every guest that comes through our doors.

CONGRATULATIONS to our latest "graduate," FRED CAMIT, who's retiring at the end of this month as head of the Polynesian Cultural Center's Management Information Services (MIS) department and a member of the Officer Team. He has spent 34 years with the PCC.

Sending aloha and prayers to our beloved Uncle Benny, longtime PCC employee and entertainer, who is battling a rare type of lymphoma cancer.

If you would like to help, please join us on Saturday, May 31 from 9a to 12p for a free benefit concert and fundraiser to raise money for his medical expenses including a critical stem cell transplant. Enjoy live entertainment from Weldon Kekauoha, TeHaMata, the Tonga Sisters, Miss Aloha Hula 2014 Kealohilani Tara Eliga Serrao, and more. Entry is free, but a donation of $10 (or more) is encouraged and will be accepted at the door.

status_message:
We'd like to thank the Hawai'i Academy of Recording Arts for presenting the Polynesian Cultural Center with the Krash Kealoha Lifetime Achievement Award.

We accept this award on behalf of those who had a vision of this place, the labor missionaries who built the center, the current and past presidents/CEOs and board members, the pioneers and PCC alumni who paved the way for the employees today so that we can enjoy and continue the center's legacy for another 50 years. Big mahalo and congratulations, PCC!!!!!

The award will be recognized at the upcoming televised 2014 Na Hoku Hanohano Awards on May 24th.

status_message:
CONGRATULATIONS to the group winners:

‚Ä¢ 1st place ‚Äî the Vaimatina Boys: Alex Galea'i, Quest Ava, Malik Ava and KJ Ahloy

‚Ä¢ 1st runner-up ‚Äî the Mauga M≈´ boys: MƒÅlosi Mata'afƒÅ-Alferos, Matagi Lilo, Mose Lilo and Jiovanni Tafisi

‚Ä¢ 2nd runner-up ‚Äî the Vaimatina Girls of Laie: Jeralee Galea'i, Aahliya Ava and Chandae Ava

CONGRATULATIONS: For those who stayed to the end of tonight's World Fireknife Championships, the THREE FINALISTS (in no particular order) are:

‚Ä¢ FALANIKO PENESA from Samoa by way of Hong Kong Disneyland
‚Ä¢ MƒÄL≈å "MJ" MATA'U of Laie
‚Ä¢ VIA "VJ" TIUMALU from Orlando, Florida
The first of three groups, the Vaimatina Girls from Laie.
KUINISƒí LEIATAUA of Honolulu turned in the last semifinal performance ‚Äî very impressive ‚Äî at almost 1:00 a.m. It's been a long, but great night of world championship fire knife competition.

NAKAYA SUGURU from Fukushima, Japan, taught himself knife dancing after he lost his job several years ago . . . and ‚Äî no surprise ‚Äî he now dances professionally back home. He's terrific, and even looks sorta' Samoan.
FALANIKO PENESA from Samoa by way of Hong Kong Disneyland: A great showman who gives it everything on stage. Incredible knife dancing.
MƒÄL≈å "MJ" MATA'U ‚Äî a hometown Laie boy and crowd pleaser.

MAKANA GANON of Waialua.

We've been watching HALE MOTU'APUAKA from Aiea, Oahu, knife dance on this stage since he was three-years-old: He‚Äôs the real deal ‚Äî fantastic!

status_message: Tickets for the '2014 High School Samoa Festival' on Saturday, May 10th are going fast! Make your reservations now to secure your seats for this exciting cultural extravaganza! These young High School students have been practicing long & hard to strut their stuff at the festival ... You definitely don't want to miss out!  Call 293-3333 to get your tickets before they sell out completely.

WALLEN TE'O from Waimanalo, Oahu: very polished.

INTERMEDIATE DIVISION CHAMPIONS (ages 12-17): (left-right) former PCC board member Kalo Mataele Soukop; HUNTER NERY of Waialua, Oahu,, 2nd runner-up; HALE MOTU'APUAKA from Aiea, Oahu, 2014 winner; WALLEN TE'O from Waimanalo, Oahu, 1st runner-up; and Logo Apelu, PCC Chief Operating Officer.

JUNIOR DIVISION CHAMPIONS (ages 6-11): (left-right, competitors) MOSE LILO from Ewa Beach, 2nd runner-up; DAYTON DAONG from Waipahu, 2014 winner; VINCENT GALEA'I of Laie, 1st runner-up; (back row): Logo Apelu, PCC Chief Operating Officer (left); former board of directors member Kalo Mataele Soukop; and Delsa Atoa Moe, PCC Director of Cultural Presentations and co-emcee for the evening.
Another of the many Galea'i family knife dancers from Laie: VICESON GALEA'I. Three knives, too. Impressive.

status_message:
Are you ready for tonight? The World Fire knife competition 2014 will kick off this evening at 7:45 at Polynesian Cultural Center!
You can watch the event live at http://worldfireknife.com/

Look who came to visit us! Tune in to Hawaii News Now tomorrow (Wednesday) morning at 5:25 a.m. and 7:20 a.m. to learn more about the World Fireknife Championships. Thanks to Team Mauga Mu for giving Hawaii a taste of what to expect at this year's competition.

World Fire Knife Competition started in 1992 and this is the 22nd year.
Past champions are from all over the world including Samoa, Cook Island, US and Tahiti.
This year competitors from all over the world are excited to show you their trained skills!

Here is a video clip of the performance done by last year champion Joseph Cadousteau! http://worldfireknife.com/

 http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Us7GwZbVDxY

Celebrate May Day at the Polynesia Cultural Center.  http://www.polynesia.com/hawaii-residents/annual-pass.html
PCC's promo team invades Eat the Street.
PCC at Eat the Street in Kakaako

We'll be at Eat the Street today, with performances from the cast of our award winning evening show Ha: Breath of Life. Don't miss out ‚Äì free parking, more than 40 food vendors, plus stop by our booth to meet the cast, weave a fish out of palm fronds, and enter for a chance to win some great prizes including tickets to the World Fireknife Championship in May. #eatthestreet
Mahalo to Florida Georgia Line for coming to the Polynesian Cultural Center and for visiting with the cast of HA: Breath of Life.

Happy Aloha Friday.  The 2014 World Fireknife Championships is slated to start May 7th.  All those who would like to compete can download the application form.
The Tahitian village welcomes Her Royal Highness with the fast hip shaking dance they are so well know for.
The Village of Aotearoa welcome her Royal Highness with a beautiful song from their Maori culture.
The Fijian village also pays their respects to Her a Royal Highness with a lively dance.
As Her Royal Highness watches from a replica of her summer palace, the Samoan village at the PCC honor her with a Taualuga dance.
The PCC welcomes Her Royal Highness Queen Nanasi Pauu Tukuaho of the Kingdom of Tonga.
A big MAHALO to Bernice Shwydiuk on her 25th visit to the Polynesian Cultural Center.  Like all who have visited the center.  Thank you for being apart of our Ohana!

Polynesian Cultural Center President & CEO Alfred Grace participated in the groundbreaking ceremonies for the new Courtyard by Marriott Hotel that will be built just makai (seaward) of the PCC. It's estimated the new 144-room hotel will take approximately 15 months to complete (i.e. it should tentatively open in summer 2015).

As one of two 45-year PCC veterans, Hawaiian cultural expert Cy Bridges shared his mana'o on behalf of the many Polynesian Cultural Center employees recognized this morning for their years of service: Bridges spoke of meeting his wife, Iraani, at the Center and of how it has touched the lives of many people. He also praised those early cultural experts from throughout Polynesia who gave the PCC its credibility 50 years ago. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)
Our dancers strike a pose in between takes.

status_message: Don't forget that PCC has a special Valentine's Day event.  Book you're special Dinner & Concert now.
Happy Aloha Friday.  If you're in Hawai'i stay dry.  If you're in the mainland stay warm.

To all the fellas.  If you don't have any plans for Valentine's Day. Don't worry.  We've got you covered.  Bring your wife to our Valentine's Dinner & Dance.  We've got the food and entertainment.  You bring your appetite and dance moves.
In a few days it will be Valentine's Day.  We'd like to hear your ideas on how to put a Polynesian twist on this special day.

The Polynesian Cultural Center is inviting kama‚ÄòƒÅina to enjoy a romantic Valentine‚Äôs Day evening featuring a buffet dinner in the award-winning Gateway Restaurant and concert by Hawai‚Äòi‚Äôs own, Irie Love.

Executive Chef Hector Morales has crafted a special menu for couples that includes creamy shrimp scampi, a prime rib carving station, salmon with black bean sauce, crispy oven-baked chicken with mushroom sauce, and island kalbi ribs.
Inaugural members of the Polynesian Football Hall of Fame and party begin a special canoe ride at the Polynesian Cultural Center. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)

Former San Francisco 49er Jesse Sapolu (right) and Denver Bronco player Ma'a Tanuvasa present PCC Chief Operating Officer Logo Apelu with a Polynesian Football Hall of Fame helmet. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)

The Polynesian Football Hall of Fame meets in the Hale Aloha on January 24, 2014 to announce its association with and upcoming museum at the Polynesian Cultural Center (former San Francisco 49er Jesse Sapolu at the microphone). (PCC photo by Mike Foley)
The first class of inductees to the Polynesian Football Hall of Fame take a canoe tour of the PCC which will house the Polynesian Hall of fame exhibit beginning in 2015.

status_message: Cheehoo........The Polynesian Cultural Center will be the new home of the Polynesian Football Hall of Fame.  The exhibit will open January 2015.
Vai Sikahema opens up our special news conference.
Getting ready for today's big community event with the new Polynesian Hall of Fame inductees.
Question:  Which college team has the most Polynesian players on their roster?
Join us for this special livestream of the Enshrinement Ceremony for the first class of inductees into the Polynesian Football Hall of Fame. The ceremony will be this Thursday at 6:30 (HST).

Who is the first Polynesian of Maori ancestry, and from New Zealand to play in the NFL? Hint: He was an all Pac-10 selection, won a National championship, a 3-time Super Bowl Champ, and played in the NFL for 10 years.
Pro Bowl Week questions:  1. How many Polynesians are in this years Pro Bowl? Names?  2.  How may Polynesians have been selected to the Pro Bowl since its inception? Names?
Ka PƒÅ Nani 'o Lilinoe dancers perform "Sophisticated Hula" during the Polynesian Cultural Center's annual Moanikeala Hula Festival (PCC photo by Mike Foley).
A NƒÅ Pua 'o Keko'olani soloist performs a Laieikawai dance in honor of the Polynesian Cultural Center's annual Moanikeala Hula Festival (PCC photo by Mike Foley).

The PCC presented its 2014 Kau i Ka Wekiu Award (recognizing outstanding alumni for their achievements) to Peter Kawaimaka Lonoae'a during the January 18 Moanikeala Hula Festival in the Pacific Theater.

Kawaimaka worked at the Center as a CCH student in the early 1970s and went on to distinguish himself as a Hawaiian cultural educator (now retired). He said his real interest in Hawaiian and other island cultures began at CCH [the Church College of Hawaii, renamed BYU-Hawaii in 1974]. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)
At the end, everyone who knew it was invited to dance hula to the theme song, "Moanikeala," which was written by Aunty Lena Machado for Aunty Sally ‚Äî the PCC's first kumu hula.
Aunty Kela Miller's Halau Hula o Kekela.
Aunty Margie Kekauoha dances solo hula to "Beyond the Reef," the same hula she did at the PCC when it opened in 1963. (PCC photo by Mike Foley)

status_message: Happy Aloha Friday.  Have a great weekend, and stay warm!
Thanks for all the great responses.  There is still time to win our Ali'i Luau packages for you and four of your friends.  Just take our online survey and you will automatically be entered.

Hula halau from across Hawai'i and Japan come together for the Annual Moanikeala Festival held at the Polynesian Cultural Centers Pacific Theater. Beautiful vestments and fragrant flowers accentuated the dancers graceful movements as they told the story of Hawai'i‚Äôs past, present and future. Call 808-293-3333 for tickets.
You could be eligible to win our Ali'i Luau package for you and four of your friends if you take our online survey. We will randomly choose a winner on January 31st, so take the survey today!

For 2014 we'd like to know what you'd like us to post on Facebook.  Is it our cultural events, employee updates, or would you like us to post Polynesian recipes?  Whatever it is, we want to know.  .  
As an added bonus, all those who participate in the survey will have a chance to win an Ali'i Luau package for them and four of their friends.  We will randomly choose a winner from the list of survey participants on January 31st.  Mahalo!

At the end of our magnificent Golden Anniversary alumni reunion tonight, September 8, 2013, PCC President & CEO Al Grace ‚Äî one of our very own ‚Äî closed the final activity, the testimony meeting in the BYUH CAC, with these words:

‚ÄúI know that we all look back on this place with love, great gratitude and fondness, because in our lives, many of the most important we have done happened in this place: For many of us, we gained an education here. We also fell in love. We married in the House of the Lord. We gave birth to our first children. I can‚Äôt tell you how many people have come back and said, my first child was born here. These are lifetime memories that will continue to make this place sacred for us.‚Äù

President Grace also encouraged all alumni to make sure we do our part to ensure that those who come after us at the Cultural Center will continue to receive and enjoy the same blessings.  

‚ÄúKnow that we love and appreciate every one of you, and know that you will always be welcome here.‚Äù

(Polynesian Cultural Center photo by PCC alum Mike Foley)

PCC alum Don Sibbett, who came from his family ranch in Wayan, Idaho, presented one of his humorous paniola songs detailing how his grandfather served a mission in the Sandwich Islands a little over a century ago, and returned with a Hawaiian bride, forever merging cowboy and coconut hats in their hapa-haole descendants . . . during today's (9/07/13) second session of the Mormon Pacific Historical Society conference, which has focused on the Polynesian Cultural Center. OK, Elvis fans . . . it's PCC's own Luse Tapusoa Magalei on the left, and Tahitian dancer extraordinaire Erena Mapuhi on the right, surrounding Vernon Presley, Elvis' father, during a break in filming a portion of "the king's" 1966 film, "Paradise Hawaiian Style," at the Polynesian Cultural Center. An earlier version of this caption mistakenly ID'd the man as Col. Tom Parker, Elvis Presley's manager, but a number of people who commented corrected us. MAHALO . . . and it's still a great picture from almost 50 years ago at the Polynesian Cultural Center.
Here's another 1963 AERIAL PHOTO of the PCC, taken from another perspective shortly before the Center opened.
The PCC . . . a few months before it opened on October 12, 1963 ‚Äî 50 years ago.

LATE 1960S: The PCC's third main entrance opened directly into the snack bar/gift shop area (at the back of the night show theater) and was used from the late 1960s until the current entrance opened as part of a major expansion on July 4, 1976.

1963 ‚Äî 50 years ago: The original entrance to the Polynesian Cultural Center was located at the end of the small street in front of Laie McDonald's, which admitted people between the Samoan and Maori Villages. A nearby sign let customers know the Center was open back in those days from  10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on "non-show" days, and from 10-to-10 on "show" days.

In the Center's earliest days, the evening show was only performed on Saturday nights. As the PCC's popularity grew, the schedule first expanded to Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday . . . and then to nightly performances (closed on Sundays) by the late 1960s. At that point the Center also expanded the capacity of the theater, and sometimes put on "double shows" to satisfy demand.

Within a few years of opening the Center's main entrance had moved about 50 yards south so that visitors entered directly into the snack bar and gift shop area at the back of the original theater (now called the Hale Aloha, where the Alii Luau is served). The PCC's main entrance located to where it is today in 1976, following major expansion and renovations.

The Polynesian Cultural Center presented a beautiful wooden bowl to the President of the Merrie Monarch, Luana Kawelu, in celebration of their 50th Anniversary.  The wooden bowl was over 44 inches in length and carved by Master Carver, Tuione Pulotu, one of the original labor missionaries who helped build the PCC in 1963. From our 'ohana to yours, Happy 50th!

30 YEARS AGO (from the pcc50.com "publications" and photo gallery sections): The late William K. Wallace II, a former Moloka'i fire chief and father of the late William K. Wallace III of Laie, was named "chief" of the Polynesian Cultural Center's Hawaiian Village.

Mark and Laura Willes, holding a Hawaiian o'o (digging tool), after the November 6, 2007, groundbreaking for the new halau wa'a (canoe compound) in the PCC's Hawaiian Village that eight months later would become the home of Iosepa, BYU-Hawaii's 57-foot twin-hulled sailing canoe.

The Willeses were major benefactors behind the project. He also served on the Polynesian Cultural Center Board of Directors for 13 years, and is a former president of the Latter-day Saint Hawaii-Honolulu Mission. She recently wrote the book "Miracle in the Pacific," that came out in December 2012 in time for the PCC's 50th anniversary.
5 YEARS AGO AT THE PCC:  President & CEO Von D. Orgill, at the community reception for the brand-new Kauaiwiulaokalani canoe halau in the Hawaiian Village, June 27, 2008 (photo by Mike Foley)

15 YEARS AGO: Steve Young took time from his 1998 Pro Bowl schedule in Honolulu to visit Laie and speak for 45 minutes to friends, fans and family in the Polynesian Cultural Center's Aloha Theater.

He regaled the audience with anecdotes from his football career, starting at age eight when his mother scolded an opponent for knocking the wind out of him with a hard tackle. As quarterback of the San Francisco 49ers who led his team to victory in the 1995 Super Bowl, earning the MVP award in the process, he said his opponents are still hitting him hard.

"I love the idea of the Polynesian Cultural Center, because culture is something we all need to hang on to," he said. He joked he wished there were also a culture center where defensive linemen could develop a little more sensitivity.

10 YEARS AGO: PCC dancer Tiffany Ieremia, 17, the daughter of PCC alumni Filipo and Dawn Ieremia of Laie, scored a page in the June 2003 nationwide issue of Seventeen Magazine:

Tiffany was part of a PCC Promo Team on tour in New York City that year when the magazine featured her beautiful smile and love of hula, which she and her sisters learned from her mother. "For me, dancing the hula is really special ‚Äî more than just an after-school job. It's something that I love to do and part of my culture that I want to continue."

That's the aloha spirit of our people at the Polynesian Cultural Center: Celebrating our 50th Anniversary throughout 2013.

status_message: Check out the more than 3,000 photos already posted to our pcc50.com Golden Anniversary website galleries, such as this one from the 2010 Te Manahua Festival of (left-right) Kim Makekau, Mark Clawson and Kimo DeCaires . . . and consider submitting some of your own!
Mahalo for visiting us!
PCC's Promotional Team visits the famous Sapporo.

Polynesian Cultural Center President & CEO Von D. Orgill (left) and his wife, Sherri, being entertained by the Tongan Village during their "graduation" part on January 18, 2013. Latter-day Saint Church leaders have called President Orgill, who has headed the PCC for approximately 13 years, to serve as president of an English-speaking mission, although they have not yet announced his specific assignment. The Orgills will leave Laie in about a month. He is the long-serving president of the Polynesian Cultural Center.

Speaking on behalf of all the Polynesian Cultural Center employees recognized on February 1, 2013, for their years of service, Fetu'u Falevai ‚Äî a 40-year veteran originally from Tonga ‚Äî said he thinks of the PCC as his "second home."

status_message:
The authors of a new book entitled "Gathering to Laie" will be on hand to talk about their new book at a book signing event held at BYU-Hawaii's campus bookstore on Friday, December 2, 2011.

The event, held from 2:30-5:00 PM, will feature authors Riley Moffat, Fred Woods, and Jeffrey Walker.

The new book is on sale at the BYU-Hawaii Bookstore in the Aloha Center of the Laie campus.
link_name: Exclusive Book Signing Event at BYU‚ÄìHawaii

status_message:
Not only has Samoa now produced its first feature film, but it's also being put forward to be nominated as best foreign language film at next year's Oscars.

"The Orator" uses a local Samoan cast and their language to capture the culture and traditions of the Pacific Island nation.

status_message: It's time for the 2011 19th Annual WORLD FIREKNIFE COMPETITION!! The HEAT is ON as we prepare to welcome the BEST Fireknife dancers in the world on stage at the Polynesian Cultural Center to battle it out THIS week Wednesday thru Saturday in order to find out who's number 1. See who has what it takes to be crowned this year's CHAMPION! Come join us for all the fun and excitement! Call (808)293-3333 for tickets!

Did you know you can help the Samoan village cook? At 12 noon daily guests help with the cooking by scraping taro and breadfruit, peeling green bananas, make palusami, put food into the umu using coconut tongs, cover it up with leaves and burlap bags and after the canoe pageant, guests uncover the umu to remove the cooked food. Do you get to sample your own cooking? You'll have to visit Samoa to find out.
Don't forget that our Kama'aina Annual Pass is now 50% off.   Visit  http://bit.ly/9902yC to purchase.

The Polynesian Cultural Center will be celebrating it's 50th Anniversary in 2013! It's going to be a great reunion and lots of fun! Keep that summer open so you can come back and join in on the festivities! It's only a year & a half away & will be here before you know it! Cheeee-hoooo!!

status_message: Dog the Bounty Hunter and his wife Beth Chapman check out the Haunted Lagoon with friends and family for Beth's Birthday

As the Laie Lady slowly retreats into the darkest corner of the Haunted Lagoon, ending her month-long reign of terror, we at the Polynesian Cultural Center wish to congratulate the tens of thousands who came out to face her -- and survived! MAHALO to all who helped make this year's Haunted Lagoon TERROR-ific!!

The screams and terror intensify as the HAUNTED LAGOON opens EVERYDAY this week, Monday thru Saturday! Save $5 on TUES, WEDS, THURS by bringing any Pepsi product to the Box Office! Last chance for all brave souls to witness the wrath of the Laie Lady! See you at the Lagoon ... IF YOU DARE!!
Just another friendly reminder that all Kama'aina Annual Pass holders can come to the Haunted Lagoon for free today.  See you at the lagoon.

Trick or Treat!!!

Here's a special treat for all Kama'aina Annual Pass Holders.  For today only, you can come to the Haunted Lagoon for free.  Just bring your Kamaaina Annual Pass with you to the Haunted Lagoon today and we'll give you one free ticket.

The Laie Lady is back!  And she's not alone ... Do you have the courage to face her and her minions??  If you think you're brave enough, come and show her what you're made of ... but don't forget ... No one can hear you scream underwater!!  buwahahahaha!!

A big
 Mahalo to all our guests who came out tonight and dared to enter the 
Haunted Lagoon. The Laie Lady will never forget you.
We all know that everyone loves clowns.
A big mahalo to all the guests who came all the way from Waianae, Ewa Beach, and Waipahu to ride the Haunted Lagoon.
Clowns, Clowns, Clowns.  For some reason no one likes our nice, happy, and very friendly killer zombie clowns.
FYI.  It looks like its going to be a big night.  Make sure you get to the Polynesian Cultural Center early, or be sure to get your "Fast Pass".
Another great article about the Haunted Lagoon.

The Polynesian Cultural Center's Haunted Lagoon starts in
less then 24 hours.  Here is a clip of some of the guest's reactions to
the new scares and surprises in store for anyone brave enough to enter the
Haunted Lagoon.
The 2010 University of Hawaii Men's Basketball Team prepare to venture into the Haunted Lagoon.
Be there to be Scared!!!

status_message: Happy 1st Birthday to Ha: Breath of Life.

Here's the last question for our Ha: Breath of Life Anniversary Contest.  Remember, the first person who posts the correct answer will win two free tickets to tommorrow nights Ha: Breath of Life Anniversary perforamance.  

The question is....

How many cast members are there in Ha: Breath of Life?

The next question is, "How many seats are there in the newly renovated Pacific Theater where Ha: Breath of Life takes place?"

Good luck.

We have about 10 minutes before our next Ha: Breath of Life question.  Please remember, the first person who answers the question correctly will receive two free tickets to the anniversary show for Ha: Breath of Life.
Today's question is, "What island cultures are represented in Ha: Breath of Life?"

Its almost time for today's question.  FYI The questions will start getting harder as we get closer to the anniversary show on Saturday.  Feel free to visit the website below to look for clues that may help you answer the upcoming questions. (hint!!!)

status_message: Thanks for playing.  We'll post another question tommorrow.  Don't forget that the Te Manahua festival starts this Friday.

We're late, but here's the next question.  The first person to respond to this question correctly, will win two free tickets to the anniversary show of Ha: Breath of Life.

What was the name of the long-running evening show that Ha: Breath of Life replaced?
We'll be posting the next question at 12pm.  We hope everyone is ready to win two free tickets to the Ha: Breath of Life anniversary show.

The first person to correctly asnwer this question about Ha: Breath of Life, will win two free tickets to this Saturday's anniversary performance.
